intro: Larnax subtriflora, commonly known as the three-flowered larnax, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Apiaceae, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, fragrant flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and thrives in full sun. Its blooming period occurs in late spring to early summer, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and ecological benefits, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and natural habitats.
